clinical_study.brief_title: Intraluminal Imaging of Duodenal Layer Morphometry in Patients With and Without Type 2 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: A Single-center, Observational, Intraluminal Imaging Study of Duodenal Layer Morphometry in Patients With and Without Type 2 Diabetes Undergoing Endoscopy of the Upper Gastrointestinal Tract

brief_summary.textblock: This observational study is conducted to determine how the duodenal layer thicknesses (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis) vary with several factors in patients with and without type 2 diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock:
Study Objectives
1. To assess duodenal layer (mucosa, submucosa and muscularis) thickness differences between patients with and without type 2 diabetes using endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and optical coherence tomography (OCT).
2. To assess duodenal layer thickness differences between patients with type 2 diabetes.
3. To assess duodenal layer thickness differences as a function of measurement location along the length of the duodenum.
4. To compare measurements obtained by endoscopic ultrasound, to those obtained by optical coherence tomography.

primary_outcome.measure: Thickness of the duodenal mucosa using OCT, and EUS if possible

secondary_outcome.measure: Thickness of the duodenal submucosa using OCT if possible, and EUS

other_outcome.measure: Thickness of the duodenal muscularis using OCT if possible, and EUS

intervention.description: Intraluminal imaging using endoscopic ultrasound and endoscopic optical coherence tomography

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing previously scheduled routine endoscopy of the upper gastrointestinal tract.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient is already scheduled for upper endoscopy with ultrasound or OCT, such as those with Barrett's esophagus.
- Patient is willing to sign an informed consent form.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient is not a candidate for endoscopy, EUS, or OCT, such as those with strictures, inflammatory disease or previous anastomosis of the esophagus or duodenum.
